Description: The SEC announced that Facebook would pay $100 million to settle allegations that it made misleading statements to investors about the possibility that the data of its customers could be misused. For more than two years, the SEC said, Facebook's public disclosures presented that risk as merely hypothetical when it knew that a third-party developer had actually engaged in such misuse.

Facebook, Inc. agreed to pay a $5 billion penalty and submit to new restrictions and a modified corporate structure that will hold the company accountable for the decisions it makes about user privacy, to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that the company violated a 2012 order by deceiving users about their ability to control the privacy of their personal information.

Facebook agreed to pay $1.95 million to the plaintiffs an provide $500,000 in credits for educational advertising as part of a settlement of allegations that its platform facilitated unlawful housing discrimination. In this and several related cases, Facebook also agreed to sweeping changes in its practices. See details at https://www.aclu.org/other/summary-settlements-between-civil-rights-advocates-and-facebook

Description: The U.S. Department of Justice announced a settlement agreement with Facebook regarding its use of the permanent labor certification program (PERM). The agreement resolved claims that Facebook routinely refused to recruit, consider or hire U.S. workers, a group that includes U.S. citizens, U.S. nationals, asylees, refugees and lawful permanent residents, for positions it had reserved for temporary visa holders in connection with the PERM process.
